awd_titl_txt: Rural Appalachian Leaders and Local Youth for STEM
awd_abstract_narration:
Inequitable access to quality STEM education is a major barrier to broader participation in STEM. This Robert Noyce Track II project will support 24 Fellows (2 cohorts of 12) who have undergraduate degrees in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) fields. These 24 Fellows will be prepared to become effective middle or secondary school mathematics or science teachers through a one-year master's program and four years of follow-up support. This project will help meet the pressing need for highly-qualified middle and secondary mathematics and science teachers in rural schools. The project aims to prepare teachers who will: 1) be confident in their STEM knowledge; 2) engage students in the activities and ways of thinking characteristic of STEM professionals; and 3) develop well-prepared students who innovate, problem solve, and are proficient technology users. The impact of the project may extend beyond the local communities. For example, the project will develop and distribute STEM resources and curricula relevant to rural communities, as well as findings about preparing STEM teachers for rural schools. 

This project includes a one-year Master's with teacher certification program designed to: (1) foster Fellows' identities as STEM teachers; 2) develop pedagogical content knowledge; (3) develop cultural competence and promote culturally relevant teaching practices for STEM disciplines that meet the diverse student needs of rural Appalachia; and (4) connect Fellows' STEM content knowledge to grades 4-12 mathematics and science classrooms. To accomplish these project goals, Fellows will take integrated STEM courses as a cohort, facilitate community education events with local community education and service organizations, and create a portfolio of activities that integrate STEM disciplines and connect to real-world problems. The project will provide Fellows with five years of financial and other support, including online and face-to-face mentoring, annual workshops held in conjunction with professional conferences, and annual summer professional development institutes. Teaching observations, surveys, interviews, artifact analysis, and comparisons of student achievement data will be used to assess the impact of the program and four-year induction support on Fellows' teaching effectiveness, development of STEM identities and pedagogical content knowledge, and inclusion of culturally relevant approaches and attributes of STEM practice in their instruction.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Rural Appalachian Leaders and Local Youth for STEM (RALLY for STEM) serves as a model for work-based and STEM-focused teacher preparation and professional development programs that leverage asset- and place-based approaches. Broader Impacts: The project has (1) increased the cadre of effective mathematics and science teachers in rural Appalachia and urban districts in Ohio and other states, addressing a crucial national shortage, with 11 Noyce STEM Fellows completing their master’s degree and some time teaching in a high-needs district and 8 of those completing all four years of required teaching in high-needs district. Additionally the project (2) offered in-person engagement events for children and families to increase access to STEM in after school, community, and university settings and provided ways for families to engage in STEM from home during the pandemic. (4) Place-based STEM materials were contributed to the Appalachian STEM Enrichment Academy. Project activities (5) cultivated university-community-school partnerships to advance teacher education, professional development, and STEM education and (6) improved mathematics and science proficiency of rural and urban students graduating from middle and high schools.

Project findings and models have been disseminated widely at professional conferences and in journals that serve mathematics and science teachers, STEM education researchers, and teacher educators. Intellectual Merit: Theoretical and conceptual models focusing on identity development, mathematical knowledge for teaching, pedagogical content knowledge, and a clinical approach to teacher education were employed to determine project findings. Results of this project are the outcomes and effectiveness of collaborative and non-traditional clinical/field experiences (e.g., STEM Camp, community engagement events) as spaces for cultivating a STEM and professional teacher identity early in educator preparation programs. Additionally, the project addressed the challenges to STEM teacher education reported in the literature and highlighted challenges particular to rural STEM teacher preparation. The project findings identified strategies for promoting teachers’ ability to support students in articulating mathematical generalizations such as collaborative design of teaching activities, in-the-moment coaching, co-teaching, and collaborative reflection supported by a self-evaluation tool, use of coordinated gestures and speech, and teacher questioning. Findings also report opportunities and tensions inherent to the integration of STEM disciplines for teaching and teacher education. RALLY for STEM promoted teacher and student proficiency in coding and programming, models for teaching advanced college mathematics in high school classrooms. During the  COVID-19 pandemic toolboxes for teaching and learning online were developed. Faculty and Noyce Fellows co-created lessons that model-based scientific inquiry, engaged student in the academic argumentation of mathematics and science, and were grounded in place-based phenomena like landslides.
